title: Scalars and vectors - change in position of object

content.question: An object is initially at the origin. The object changes its position to the right by <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> units. The object then changes its position to the left by <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> units. Which of the following correctly indicates the magnitude of the objectâ€™s change in position and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> unit, because in one dimension vectors with opposite directions have opposite signs.

<math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> unit, because the magnitude of the difference of two vectors is always equal to the difference between the magnitudes of the vectors.
<math alttext="7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>7</mn></math> units, because the magnitude of the sum of two vectors is always equal to the sum of the magnitudes of the vectors.

<math alttext="7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>7</mn></math> units, because the object moves a distance of <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> units followed by a distance of <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> units.

content.answer: <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> unit, because in one dimension vectors with opposite directions have opposite signs.
